column4: can someone please tell me how to execute a sudo command in GNOME in the gui on fiesty?
what sudo command do you need?

I need to copy a file from my home directory to the usr/share/ directory.  I was trying to use to open file browsers to drag and drop, but it says I don't have access to the directory. Even though I'm using the sudo account..
if you're using gnome.. open a terminal, and type gksudo nautilus
thanks that worked.  But it was very slow. It looked liked in the terminal it was trying to make a "secure" connection?  is that right?
yeah, but it shoudln't have been slow.
it is an older computer amdk400 or 450 with 300 megs of ram, would that make a difference?
probably.., are you running gnome?
yeah.. day to day stuff in the gui isn't really that slow though, just when I tried to sudo nautilus thing..
ok.. just remember though, sudo orks, but when you run nautilus like that, you want to gksudo, not sudo.
ok, thanks alot of the help. what does the "gk" signify?
its just a security issue of using sudo, instead of gksudo, with graphical programs... like nautilus
ok.. thanks again man..
if you're staying in CLI, sudo is fine, but if the command is going to open a graphical program and give you root access, use gksudo.
no problem
ok, sometimes I just use the gui cause it's easier, other times I use the cli and knew how to use sudo in that enviroment, I just couldn't figure out the Graphical "sudo" thing..
yeah, once you get the hang of it, its easy.. but that PC, if you start to notice serious speed problems, etc, might be a little better suited to Xubuntu..
yeah, this is just kinda of a testbed computer to check out fiesty.  I've used suse for years, so ubuntu does some things differently that is throwing me off a little..
oh i see, so you're not a complete newbie, just new to ubuntu
yeah.. ;)
gotta run, but thanks again mate!
np, take care
